Paul,

What I've experienced in the past is that constructors often times 
are declared as non-public to reenforce the intent that the given 
class be non-instantiatable.  

Obviously TestCase is abstract already within it's declaration which 
should be sufficient reenforcment already.

Is there a particular reason your attempting to instantiate the 
abstract TestCase directly as opposed to a derived class?

Regards,
Todd Viegut
----
Communication Data Services, Inc.

--- In junit@y..., "pantinori" <pantinori@y...> wrote:
> I am loading up my list of test cases from an xml file with 
something 
> like class and method.  Then using class.forname and 
> class.newinstance I would instantiate the TestCase.  I then wanted 
to 
> call TestCase.setName and then add the testcase to the testsuite.  
> unfortunately the newInstance fails because TestCase has a default 
> constructor that is not public.  :(  Is there a particular reason 
why 
> this is so?   Thanks for help.
> 
> Paul Antinori
